1.c: Cemeteries. However, they are not considered detrimental as they are very well taken care of.
1.b: Transportation schools and churches good. About 8 blocks from business section to east. On the south in C 13 there is a progressive dairy plant west of Lathrep Avenue.

areaDesc.5: All platted. Only a few homes, - built in 1929. Mostly undeveloped. Fast growing and popular because of construction of medium priced modern buildings. Good building restrictions of $5,000 and better. Both sides of Orchard Street from Washington Avenue north very good homes.

1.c: Outside city.
1.b: None, except adjacency to Racine County Club.

areaDesc.5: One resident, the Janes estate, worth approximately $15,000 and another house of 8 rooms worth $8,0000 are the outstanding homes; otherwise the area is stagnant, very sparsely settled, and with very little future.

1.c: None.
1.b: Fratt School is in center of area nad Blaire School is just southeast. Godo transportation, churches, and business. Washington Park Golf grounds on east.

2.a: Mixed. Skilled machanics, clerical, business & professional

areaDesc.5: This area is holding its own as a residential section. Known as West Racine. Very popular due to single bungalow type and younger element purchasing homes here. People living here are quite thrifty and show pride of ownership in homes. Streets, shrubs, gardens and trees very well kept up.

1.c: No paved streets, curbs nor gutters.
1.b: Transportation, churches, schools - good.

areaDesc.5: This area is fairly new and should develop into a fairly good section and eventually a better class of home is expected to be built have as the adjacent B-3 and B-4 are very good neighborhoods. Rents should advance. Very conservative mortgage loans are made here. The future is promising.

1.c: North Shore Railroad to the west.
1.b: St. Edwards Catholic School is south of 15th and west of the Chicago and North Western Railraod. Good transportation, schools, churches, and business center.

areaDesc.5: This section is part of what is known as West Racine. Has mostly 5 and 6 room bungalows and is very popular as a residential section. Prices are well maintained and the only sales being made are forced ones. The section from Cleveland Ave. to Lathrop Ave. to the west is sparsely settled. From 16 St. to the north and to the North Shore Railroad to east and Lanthrop Ave. west, values are somewhat lower due to proximity to D-9 to south where properties and houses are very poorly and cheaply constructed.

1.c: Catholic cemetery to the east and the North Shore Railroad.
1.b: Picturesque setting. Very well treed, winding raods, good schools, transportation and churches.
1.a: Level and high east of West Blvd. with ravines to north and east of area. East of West Blvd. and north of West Blvd. very low ravines.

areaDesc.5: West section of area is sparsely settled and is also high ground -- not platted. South section is level with homes well kept -- great pride in ownership. Money is learned very conservatively. The east section is sparsely settled and very low. Along Harvey Drive, West Blvd, and Shelley Drive there are several fine homes -- this section is quite desirable.

1.c: Catholic cemetery to west and Mound Cemetery to south. (However, both are very well kept up)
1.b: Good transportation, schools, church, close to business center to east.
1.a: High and level with ravine to north of Mohr Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Danes comprise the majority of inhabitants. From Chicago Ave. to to Kinsie there is a slight slope of 5 blocks to the east. The streets are well lighted and all are paved. Properties are very well kept. Fine park facilities to the southeast. McKinley Junior High School is immediately north of area.

1.c: None, except stagnant water in the river during summer months.
1.b: Good school, church, and adjacent to business section. Good transportation. Jefferson School is located in this area.
1.a: Level, sloping on west toward the Root River.

a.3: One apartment named "Will Manor" of 20 units

areaDesc.5: The Root River overflows every spring to the north of the W. 6th St. Bridge to extreme north of area. The land is low from Cliff Avenue to the river. There is the Washington Park Golf links to the southwest point of area which adds to property value adjacent thereto. Close to industry. That section of area on extreme southwest contains an apartment building named "Will Manor" of 20 units consisting of 3 - 4 rooms. This building is of brick and concrete construction, is about 10 years old, and is situated on the corner of Lafayette and W. 6th St. Directly east of the apartment is the Old Peoples Home -- very well kept.

1.c: Isolation Hospital (called the Lincoln Hospital) is to the south.
1.b: Good schools, transportation, business center, Lincoln School is east of area and adjoining. Open Air School is located north of this area. Sacred Heart Catholic School is just north of area.

p.1: Good - few for rent, if any

areaDesc.5: The area is situated on a plateau and on the west from Jefferson there is an abrupt drop to the river of 45 feet. On the extreme south there is approximately a 50 - 60 foot drop. A park has recently been made by W. P. A. on the south which is an asset to the area. The inhabitants work in various factories within easy walking distance.

1.c: Industry along the railroad to west.
1.b: Good schools, transportation, parks, churches, playgrounds, a new field house recently completed by W. P. A. is at Union (Lincoln) Park on northwest section. St. Johns Neponuk Catholic School is south of Yout and west of St. Clair. The Horlick Senior High Schol is located outside on the west of area. Trinity English Lutheran School is south of Goold and west of Marquette.

areaDesc.5: On the extreme west and northwest from Lincoln School on south to Ronayne Ave. on north, property averages in age from 15 - 20 years. From Douglas Ave. on west to Goold on north to the Lake on the east to Hagerer St. on south, the area is about similar to the foregoing west and northwest description - property is well kept and same age. The German element in whole area is thrifty and properties are well kept. The greater portion of population works in the Case (Main Works) and also in the Bell City Malleable and Iron Company and Hamilton Beach Manufacturing Co. and various other factories within walking distance from their homes. The two blocks from Carliale St. on west north from High St. to Yout St. have very fine homes. The land (undeveloped) west of here is owned by Horlicks and today probably worth $1200-$1500 per acre. When developed of this land takes place it should be of high order.

1.c: Railroad to east.
1.b: Good school, transportation, and business section.

areaDesc.5: A foreign settlement, poor maintenance, railroad, and surrounded by factories in which these residents work. Some negroes. An undesirable area.

1.c: A greater portion of area is low and sometimes known as "Frogtown".
1.b: Transportation, schools, churches - good.
1.a: High and low (a drop of approximately 60 feet occurs from Chicago and North Western Railroad west to the river).

areaDesc.5: Any mortgage loans made here would be ultra-conservative. A foreign settlement with colored element. Spotted throughout. All factory laborers. An undesirable area, 2/3 of it being low land.

1.c: Transportation is not good
1.b: Good high school and park systems in south and west section of area.

areaDesc.5: Values have always been stable here because of the adjacency of the Washington Park Senior High School to the southwest. Streets are all paved and well lighted and properties taken care of. Very heavy traffic on 12th St., a thoroughfare through the center area.

1.c: St. Paul Railroad to south and North Shore Railroad to west.
1.b: Washington Park is to the north, good transportation, churches, schools and Taylor Avenue business section. The Gilbery Knapp School is on the south and the Howell School is located on northeast.

areaDesc.5: That section east of Taylor Avenue is a newer one and average 18 years in age. The majority of inhabitants in this area work in the North factory to the southeast. Streets are well paved, property well kept. Popular place for mechanics and laborers to reside. 16th Street is spotted with business. In the northwest section from Dean Blvd. to 16th Street to Washington Street, many business and professional men reside and the property values here are somewhat better. Gilbert Knapp School is in the southern portion of area.

1.c: Surrounded by industry - smoke - noise, etc.
1.b: All necessary conveniences.

areaDesc.5: Very conservative loans for home purchase are made here. A good rental area. Many rooming houses. Prices have maintained stability fairly well.

1.c: Many shacks consisting of 1 to 5 rooms.
1.b: None.

areaDesc.5: A very undesirable plat with no tendency to grow. Unimproved roads, no sewerage system, lights, transportation, etc. Quite a distance from employment

1.c: Transportation poor. No schools.
1.b: None

areaDesc.5: Spotted area. Good homes in the area suffer by the many poorly constructed ones with no basements, etc. Southwestern section is very low with stagnant water every spring. South of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad and west of West Lawn is outside the city limits.

1.c: Dairy -- early hours of rising, wagons, etc. This dairy is located south of Durand Avenue.
1.b: "The new Mitchell Junior High School is in this area. Churches, good transportation, and business section to north on Taylor Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Comparatively new area. Very thrifty people and they show an exceptional desire for home ownership. Most of the inhabitants work in the J. I. Case Company South Works on the east. Area has all modern utilities. The extreme southwest section of area has a better class of bungalow homes ranging between $7,000 and $7,500 and has between 20 and 35 of these good homes. This section is outside city limits. *This new high school was constructed in 1936 by W. P. A. progress.

1.c: Railroad to north, also factories to north and east. Quite smoky and dirty.
1.b: None except adjacent to B-5; church, school and transportation O.K.

areaDesc.5: The northwest section has many 1 1/2 story single homes of 5 and 6 rooms. The southwest section consists mostly of single homes of the bungalow type with the exception of Taylor Avenue which has several apartments -- it is also a business street. A large apartment building on Meachem and Taylor Avenue is now owned by the First National Bank. The adjacency to Nash Motors keeps rentals and property values stready.

1.c: Colored element and industry, railroads, smoke, etc.
1.b: Good transportation.

areaDesc.5: Colored element is located from Philly Avenue to Kearney Avenue on DeKoven Avenue. Homes from 20th Street to 21st Avenue are newer and of the bungalow type. Convenient to industry. No upward trend expected for many years, if any.

1.c: Poor transportation
1.b: Schools fairly close.

areaDesc.5: Very sparsely settled. The two sections south of Durand are outside city limits.

1.c: None.
1.b: Good school. Transportation is about 4 blocks to the north (the Taylor Avenue bus line).
1.a: Center of western section is low, otherwise area is level.

areaDesc.5: Very much spotted with homes ranging from $8,000 to $12,000 and some from $5,500. Vacant land is steady and commands good prices along Taylor Avenue, otherwise area is sparsely settled. Outside city limits.

1.c: No paving or sewerage. Factories, smoke, etc.
1.b: Poor transportation. No churches. Schools are at a distance. Poor business center.

areaDesc.5: Sparsely settled area - not a desirable one for residential purposes. Residents mostly work in J. I. Case Company South Works.

1.c: Railroad to west and industry.
1.b: Good schools, transportation, church, business center. The Vocational school is located in extreme north of area, also Franklin Junior High School.
1.a: Level - except a small decline from Center Street and Washington Avenue to 13th Street to the sotuh, to the Chicago Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad to the west.

areaDesc.5: The area from 13th Street south to 17th Street and west to Racine Street is level. Also the section from 17th to 21st on Mead Street west on 21st to the Chicago and North Western Railroad and north to 17th is level. The only time a demand for rents exists here is when (as is now) there is a shortage of homes for rent. The section south of 17th consists entirely of a factory district and is very undesirable. Along the Chicago Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad to  the east is popular.

1.c: Interurban line running north and south through area -- very noisy and annoying at night.
1.b: Everything necessary. St. Catherine's High School is south of 12th St. and west of Park Ave. St. Mary's Catholic School is in business center just north of area. St. Rose Catholic School is north of 11th St. and west of Grand. Holy Name Catholic School is just south of 15th St. and west of Park. The Vocationa; School and Franklin Jr. High School are located on northwest of area in D-5. Winslow School is in center of area.

areaDesc.5: There are 6 apartments ranging from 15 - 40 units on the west side of Main Street from 7th to 15th Streets. From 7th to 12th Streets there is a mixture of single homes of 6 - 9 rooms, and from 14th to 16th Streets there are single homes of 8 - 9 rooms of substantial value; from DeKoven Avenue north to 14th on Park Avenue and east to the lake there are many homes from $12,000 to $20,000. This area is one where land values will remain good and probably increase due to the desirability for location of high grade apartment houses. There are several exceptionally fine homes on DeKoven near the lake. Some of the old homes in this area cost up to $50,000 but after these old families die off these homes will be of little value, although the value of the ground.

1.c: Railroad to west and industry all around area.
1.b: St. John's Lutheran School is south of St. Patrick Street and west of N. Wisconsin. Garfield School is on southwest corner. St. Patrick's School is east of center of area. Close to industry and business.

areaDesc.5: 20% Jews along railroad (junk yards) to west. Only foreign element will buy any property in this area. This is one of the oldest sections in the city. Homes are old and hard to maintain. A very undesirable area rapidly on deline - north to High Street. St. Joseph's Catholic School is south of St. Patrick Street and east of Erie Street. Washington Junior High is in north center of area. Janes School is on east - north of Barker Street.

1.c: None.
1.b: Transportation, schools and churches excellent. Neighboring stores good. (Roosevelt School is in center of area)

2.a: White-collar & busines men with small % of factory workers

areaDesc.5: This area is well supplied with all conveniences. It will continue to be a popular area for residential homes.

1.c: Schools far away, no close churches, poor transportation.
1.b: None (except adjacency to A1 and B1 on east)

areaDesc.5: Notwithstanding adjacency to A1 and B1, this area does not warrant a "B" rating. The reason for this is the element residing in the west in D1 which is the lower class of foreigners (Italians predominating) and the very poor shack-like construction of homes in D1. Also, in D1 the land is low and swampy. Any chance of A1 expanding to the west is well taken care of by the 2 blacks west of N. Main Street which is mostly vacant land.

1.c: Very low and many shacks -- low class Italians -- transportation poor
1.b: None, except good school on north.
1.a: Level but slanting approximately 4 to 6 feet from raod on west to 6th Avenue; and about 2 feet from Green Street on east to 6th Avenue on west.

areaDesc.5: In that section south of North Street to Seymour the lots are 30 feet wide only. The section north of North Street to the city limits is not platted. This area has no future for a long time. Poor class of residents. In the northwest section of area the North Racine School is located.

1.c: No business center, no churches, and no transportation north of August Avenue.
1.b: Bus line runs north to Augusta Avenue and north Main Street. Good country grammar school outside city limits on north end.
1.a: Level. Severe drop to Lake Michigan - about 70 degree angle. (This drop starts at from 80 to 100 feet from the water's edge.)

k.1: Very limited (Only a very few buyers for this class of property.)

areaDesc.5: A portion of this area on extreme north is outside the city limits. This is the most desirable section of Racine in which to live. There is no particular demand for homes here due to the limited number of business and professional men who can buy homes in this area. Very well restricted and very few, if any homes for sale. They have been built for owners and not for sale. The 2 blocks west of N. Main Street are very sparsely settled and unlikely to expand due to the undesirable elements to west in the C1 and D1. These 2 blocks will be used as a bumper to protext A1, the prices of this vacant land being held high enough to prevent the enroachment of this foreign element. Few, if any, rentable properties.

1.c: None, except tavern recently built to the north.
1.b: About 1 1/2 miles from good school to the east. Area well timbered with oak trees.

a.1: Single 6 rm. bungalows 2 story 7 rm. & 1 1/2 story

areaDesc.5: Outside city limits. Garrety's Grove. Mostly vacant property. The Lots are large sized and area was developed because of oak trees. It is about 3 miles west of teh city on Trunk Highway "K" and 38.

1.c: None, except the inconvenience of getting to town in winter
1.b: Golf course to the east. Good school.

2.f: Some in southern section of area

areaDesc.5: Evenutally this area should develop. The section to the south is largely comprised of laborers seeking cheaper grade of home (spotted). The professional class lives in the northern section of area. In the southern section of area, the grade of home runs from $3,500 to $5,000 frame, 1 1/2 story, 5-room bungalows and frame cottages. Both section of area are 85 - 90% vacant.

1.c: Close to North Shore, R. R. on west and St. Paul R. R. to the north.
1.b: Good schools, transportation, churches, parks and close to business section of Taylor Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Accessible to Nash Motor factory on east. About 60% of the inhabitants work there.

1.c: To the south of J. I. Case South Works is Lakeside with salons, night clubs, colored element, etc.
1.b: Good schools - near DeKoven Academy on east. Stephen Bull School is in this area. Churches (Polish) and Racine Street business section to the west.

areaDesc.5: This is a Polish settlement - about 80% of the foreigners are Poles. These Poles are considered of the better or best class in the city. Most of the inhabitants are employed at J. I. Case South Works and Nash Motors, also the LAkeside Malleable Casting Company. Employment at the Case factory has been steady except for strike periods of 2 - 3 months. Nash Motors are idle generally from September to March yearly. South of this area is vacant park land and Racine Sewerage Disposal Plant now under construction. This no considered detrimental.
